content.description: Starts with some juggy holds, gets dirty and slopey as you move up.Olson calls this a good trad lead route, but I've only TRed it.
content.protection: A couple bolts down low, Gear to 2" near the top
content.location: Obvious seam in the rock with an adjoining slanting seam at the bottom. From the top out trail, you'll see the anchors on the wall behind the trail, you'll need to use a rope protector or set a rebelay where your rope runs over the edge, there's a good crack for cams at the edge that you can set before you go over the edge.
Arete / nose on the right hand endge of the main wall

content.description: Closed up crack system. Very mossy at the top
content.protection: 3 QDs and gear to 2". Bolted anchor with chains.
content.location: Bolted line immediately climbers right of Dreamin'

content.description: Large holds to start, a few powerful moves then can veer left to the mossy crack (1"-2" gear) or right to merge with Dreamin. Holds thin near the top.
content.protection: Bolt with 1"-2" gear placements if finish via the crack
content.location: Near center of the crag, bolted line along the blocky flake to the left of the obvious tree.

content.description: The classic climb at KCC and a must do. Starts with a balancy 5.9, then powers into a slightly overhung face crux. Final move can be pinch smeared to avoid a large mantle.
content.location: Leftmost bolt line that is clear of moss.

content.description: Easier climbing on good holds to start, becomes more difficult towards the top. The tree potentially poses some risk on lead, be mindful.
content.protection: 4-5 Bolts. Chains w/ quick-links at anchor.
content.location: Near the middle of the crag, a bolted line on the left side of a crack. Closest route to the obvious tree located approximately 3 feet from the wall.
Righthand most climb, on the seperate rock

content.description: Small roadside crag just north of Highway 26. Approximately a dozen climbs. North facing and stays mostly shaded. Currently many routes have significant moss growth. Would improve with use.
